newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Rashid laments high Malaysian interest rate.
newsitem.headline: Rashid laments high Malaysian interest rate.

text.p: The executive chairman of Rashid Hussain Bhd, Malaysia's largest stockbroking group, said on Wednesday he was not happy with the country's high interest rate regime.
"No businessman can be comfortable with that level of interest rates," Abdul Rashid Hussain told reporters after delivering a speech at a conference.
"Higher interest rates do damage to the equity market," said Abdul Rashid, also executive chairman of financial services firm RHB Capital Bhd.

Malaysian interest rates have been on a general uptrend in the last few weeks as the central bank, Bank Negara, battled to defend the ringgit against currency speculators. But rates have since eased as Bank Negara let market forces determine the ringgit's level.
On Wednesday, the three-month Kuala Lumpur Offered Rate (KLIBOR) was fixed at 10.3 percent at 0300 GMT, lower than 11.3 percent on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, Acting Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said he did not foresee interest rates continuing to rise.
Echoing Anwar's comments on Tuesday, Rashid said: "I believe stabilisation (of the ringgit) is the answer".
